Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Genetics of Convergence at Multiple Levels: Evolution of Colorful Dewlaps in Anolis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Convergent evolution of similar form by distantly related species is a common feature of organismal evolution and among the most tangible signatures of natural selection. Anolis lizards in the Caribbean provide a textbook example, with species similar in morphology, ecology and behavior arising independently in similar habitats on each of the Greater Antillean islands. This project exploits the diversity and repeated evolution of coloration in Anolis lizards to study the genetic basis of convergent evolution. Using RNA-sequencing and detailed phenotypic characterization, this study will identify genes associated with colorful pigmentation and determine if convergence results from changes in the same genes and developmental pathways. Illuminating the genetics of convergent evolution will enrich our understanding of the evolutionary process, and insight into the genetics of colorful pigmentation will have far-reaching impact on the study of vertebrate biology.

Because the diversity in Anolis dewlap color is so striking, this project presents a visually appealing example of evolution with broader impact on the educational and general community. The principal investigators will design a public exhibit at the Harvard Museum of Natural History to highlight the genetic basis of convergent evolution and coloration, illuminate the research process, and teach basic lessons about adaptive radiation and evolution. The exhibit will be made available to other museums. Also, undergraduates in this project will complete species pages for the Encyclopedia of Life for each species in this study. These web pages are easily accessible and will contain data summaries, photographs and videos. They will serve as useful resource for students, educators and the media.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Anolis is the largest genus of amniote vertebrates (reptiles, birds and mammals) with approximately 400 species on Caribbean islands and in Central and South America. One of the distinguishing characteristic of anoles (as they are called) is possession of a dewlap, a longitudinal flap of skin positioned on the throat that can be unfurled for territorial, mating and anti-predator displays. Males of all but two anoles species possess dewlaps, as do females of many species. Dewlaps vary in colors and patterns and coexisting species always differ in dewlap size, color or pattern. Experimental data confirms that anoles use the dewlap as a means of distinguishing members of their own species from members of other species. In addition, it is possible that females choose among males based on their dewlap configuration.

This project aimed to unravel the underlying genetic changes responsible for the enormous variation in dewlap pigmentation and morphology between diverse species that inhabit unique ecological niches, within a single polymorphic species, and across ontogeny as the dewlap develops and gains pigments. To accomplish these goals, this work combined field collections, morphological measurements (from pigment quantification to histological staining) and molecular bench work (from liquid chromatography to transcriptomic analysis). Comparative gene expression analyses revealed two major changes in genetic networks that control: (1) pigment synthesis, likely involving changes to only a handful of pigment pathway genes, and (2) tissue architecture, primarily involving the number, size and density of scales.  In both cases, changes to pigmentation and scale morphology are specific to the dewlap, differing from, for example, the dorsal or ventral body skin. Moreover, for pigment to be visible, a reduction in the overlying scales must also evolve, suggesting these traits act in concert. Thus, we have identified key genes involved in the evolution of the dewlap as a signaling mechanism, involved in pigmentation and scale development, thus gaining insight into how novel traits evolve. 

In addition to its intellectual merit, this project involved the interdisciplinary training of a postdoctoral fellow, who is now a full-time bioinformatician, as well as four undergraduate scholars. Over one hundred anole specimens were curated and accessioned in the Department of Herpetology in the Museum of Comparative Zoology, where they can be loaned and studied by researchers world-wide. Finally, as part of the broader impact of this work, anole lizards and their dewlaps feature prominently in a public exhibit entitled “Evolving Islands” at the Harvard University Museum of Natural History. In addition to the displays of specimen, the 2-year-exhibit includes a popular video of co-PI Losos explaining his research on the evolution of island-dwelling anole lizards. The museum receives over 180,000 visitors per year, including 30,000 K-12 students.  In sum, this work contributed to both our detailed understanding of the genetics and evolution of novel traits, using anole dewlaps as a model system, and the education of both Harvard trainees and the general public on basic principles of genetics and evolutionary biology.
